citances.sentence: The appellant sought the issue of the constitutional writs before the Federal Magistrates Court of Australia on the footing that the Tribunal had fallen into jurisdictional error by misconstruing the statutory obligation to hold a meeting and had proceeded to reach a decision without affording the appellant an opportunity to appear before it and give evidence and present arguments. The resolution of that challenge fell to be determined as a question of construction of the provisions of the Migration Act in the context of a decision of the Full Court of this Court in Hasran v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2010] FCAFC 40 ; (2010) 183 FCR 413 constituted by Jacobson, Gilmour and Foster JJ; the affirmation by the Court in Hasran of the correctness of the decision of this Court in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 per Tracey J and whether any relevant point of distinction arises (so far as might be relevant to the facts of this case) concerning the application of those authorities, as suggested in the reasoning of a decision of the Federal Magistrates Court of Australia in Kumar v Minister for Immigration & Citizenship [2010] FMCA 614.

The review applicant did not provide the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to an interview, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421.

Further, the Tribunal, pursuant to s. 360 has made a decision on the review without inviting the applicant to appear before it. The Tribunal finds that s. 359C(2) applies and therefore s. 360(2)(c) is relevant. The Tribunal finds that it is unable to allow the applicant to appear before it ( MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 and M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247). Pursuant to s. 360 and s. 363A of the Act, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision on the review without holding a hearing.
The applicant should receive relief in the form of the constitutional writs of certiorari and mandamus. I will so order. [1]

In addition, the Tribunal has had regard to the fact that the Courts have held that where an applicant fails to respond to such a written invitation within the prescribed period, section 363A of the Act precludes the Tribunal from offering an applicant a hearing: See Hasran v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2010] FCAFC 40 ; M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 ; Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498.

His Honour distinguished the Federal Court decisions of Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498 , M v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 and Hasran v Minister for Immigration & Citizenship [2010] FCAFC 40 ; (2010) 183 FCR 413 on the basis that those cases were concerned with the inability of the Tribunal to invite an applicant to attend a hearing where there had been a failure to respond to a s.359 or a s.359A notice within the prescribed period and were not concerned with the Tribunal's cancellation of a hearing to which the applicant had already been validly invited.

At the time of writing this decision the applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period and no further extension has been requested or granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if an applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421.

At the time of writing this decision the applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period and no further extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if an applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421.

The applicant has not provided the comments or response within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50]; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421.

The applicant made no further submissions. The Minister filed additional submissions on 31 August 2010 relevantly as follows: The construction and application of s.363A and the related provisions of Part 5 of Division 5 of the Act were explained by the Full Court of the Federal Court in Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs v Sun & Anor [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498 ("Sun") and affirmed by Tracey J in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 ("M"). These decisions were affirmed by the decision of the Full Court of the Federal Court in Hasran v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2010] FCAFC 40. In Sun , the Full Court said at [50]: Section 360(3) disentitles a visa applicant from appearing before the Tribunal if any of the circumstances in s 360(2) apply, relevantly here if s 359C(2) applies to the first respondent.

In addition, the Tribunal has had regard to the fact that the Courts have held that where an applicant fails to respond to such a written invitation within the prescribed period, section 363A of the Act precludes the Tribunal from offering an applicant a hearing: See Hasran v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2010] FCAFC 40 (5 May 2010); M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs ; [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 ; Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498.

In addition, the Tribunal has had regard to the fact that the Courts have held that where an application fails to respond to such a written invitation within the prescribed period, section 363A of the Act precludes the Tribunal from offering an applicant a hearing: See Hasran v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2010] FCAFC 40 (5 May 2010); M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 ; Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498.

As the visa applicant has failed to provide comments requested before the time for giving it has passed, subsections 359C(1) and (2) apply and the Tribunal may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the information. Further, the Tribunal observes that as subsections 359C(1) and (2) apply to the visa applicant, subsection 360(3) states that the visa applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. Under section 363A the Tribunal does not have the power to permit a person to do something he or she is not entitled to do, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise. Section 360 does not provide otherwise. In addition, the Tribunal notes that the decision in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing, notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so.

The applicant did not provide the information that the Tribunal invited her to provide in the s.359 letter by 22 June 2010 neither did she ask for an extension of time. In the circumstances where the applicant did not provide the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. Accordingly, on 24 June 2010, the Tribunal cancelled the applicant's hearing that was scheduled for 28 June 2010.

The applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if an applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50]; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The Tribunal has decided to proceed to decision without taking further steps to obtain the information. The applicant was informed in a letter of the Tribunal dated 9 April 2010 that an extension of time had not been granted. The Tribunal informed the applicant that it would take into account any evidence or written arguments received before the Tribunal makes its decision. However, at the time of the Tribunal's decision no further correspondence, evidence or submissions have been received from the applicant.

The review applicant did not provide the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421.

The review applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The Tribunal has decided to proceed to decision without taking further steps to obtain the information in writing.

The review applicant has not provided the information and comments within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50]; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50]; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. 21 His Honour referred to and applied the decision of Tracey J in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 (" M ") which explained the operation of s 363A.

The review applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The Tribunal has decided to proceed to decision without taking further steps to obtain the information.

The applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period and no extension has been granted. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if an applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50]; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The Tribunal has decided to proceed to decision without taking further steps to obtain the information.

As a result of the applicant's failure to respond to the Tribunal's letter within the prescribed time period, he lost his entitlement to be invited to a hearing pursuant to s.360(3) and the Tribunal was precluded from offering him a hearing in this circumstance: s.363A of the Act; MIMIA v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; Lee v MIAC [2007] FMCA 1802. Accordingly, a hearing in relation to his case could not be conducted and the Tribunal decided to make a decision on the review on the basis of the evidence before it without taking any further action to obtain any comments or additional information.

The review applicant has not provided the information within the prescribed period as extended. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit the review applicant to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The Tribunal has decided to proceed to decision without taking further steps to obtain the information.

In any event, in a letter of 10 March 2010 the Tribunal invited the applicant to comment on or respond to information under s.359A of the Act. Again, this letter was sent to the applicant both at the address given in his review application and the Seven Hills address that had been given to the Tribunal orally. The Tribunal did not receive any comments or response within the period for response. As the applicant was invited to comment on information under s.359A, and did not give comments before the time for giving them had passed, s.359C(2) of the Act applies to him. In accordance with s.360(3), he is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. Authorities such as MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 , M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247 , Lee v MIAC & Anor [2007] FMCA 1802 , Khant v MIAC [2009] FMCA 328 at [34] and Singh v MIAC [2009] FMCA 281 at [26] indicate that the effect of s.363A is that the Tribunal is unable to permit the applicant to appear before it in these circumstances.

In addition, the Tribunal notes that the decision in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so.

The Tribunal did not receive any comments or response within the period for response. Authorities such as MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 , M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247 , Lee v MIAC & Anor [2007] FMCA 1802 , Khant v MIAC [2009] FMCA 328 at [34] and Singh v MIAC [2009] FMCA 281 at [26] indicate that the effect of s.363A is that the Tribunal is unable to permit the applicant to appear before it in these circumstances. Nevertheless, as set out below the Tribunal has invited the applicant to comment on, or respond to, further information. On 26 November 2009, the Tribunal received from the applicant's representative a request for an extension of time in which the representative indicated that he had been unsuccessful in attempts to contact his client. He requested a further two weeks in which to respond. The Tribunal is of the view that it is not empowered to exercise its power under ss.359B(4) to extend the period to respond to an invitation where the request for extension is received after the initial prescribed period has expired (for instance, Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421 at [45] - [46]; M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247). On 27 November 2009, an officer of the Tribunal contacted the applicant's representative and informed him that the Tribunal had not granted an extension of time. However, the officer indicated that the Tribunal did not intend to make a decision on the matter prior to 7 December 2009 and that it would consider any submissions received before a decision was made.

Those comments were endorsed by Tracey J in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333. In that case, his Honour said: [52] In any event, it may be doubted that there was scope for the Tribunal, even if it had been minded to do so, to extend time to comply with the request made on 28 February 2005, after the period stipulated for compliance in that letter had passed. Section 359B(4) of the Act is cast in the present tense ("If a person is to respond" and "the response is to be made"). This, as the Full Court noted in Sun (146 FCR at 509-510) suggests that any application for an enlargement of time must be made while the time stipulated in the original letter of request is still running. The Full Court did not find it necessary to determine the question (see at 510) but, in Usman v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FMCA 966 at [44], Pascoe CFM held that the power granted by s 359B(4) of the Act could only be exercised within the period allowed when the original request was made. Had it been necessary to do so I would have held that the Tribunal could not have enlarged time pursuant to s 359B(4) of the Act after, at the latest, 6 April 2005.

Mr Reilly's response to this ground was to refer the Court to Minister for Immigration and Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498 (" Sun "), a later Full Court authority to Uddin , and to M v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 (" M " ). His submission was that the law was clear and that, notwithstanding what the applicant sought to draw from Uddin , Sun was later Full Court authority, and as such, is clearly binding on this Court. That while M was the judgment of a single judge sitting in the Federal Court's original jurisdiction, it should be followed.

The review applicant has not provided the information and comments within the prescribed period. In these circumstances, s.359C applies and pursuant to s.360(3) the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. The effect of s.363A of the Act is that if a review applicant has no entitlement to a hearing, the Tribunal has no discretion to permit him or her to appear: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [46] ; MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 at [50] ; and Xue v MIAC [2009] FMCA 421. The Tribunal has decided to proceed to decision without taking further steps to obtain the information and comments.

As the visa applicant has failed to give the information and comments requested before the time for giving it has passed, subsections 359C(1) and (2) apply and the Tribunal may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the information. Further, the Tribunal observes that as subsections 359C(1) and (2) apply to the visa applicant, subsection 360(3) states that the visa applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. Under section 363A the Tribunal does not have the power to permit a person to do something he or she is not entitled to do, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise. Section 360 does not provide otherwise. In addition, the Tribunal notes that the decision in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing, notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so. Notwithstanding, the Tribunal has also had regard to the fact that Riley FM in Khergamwala v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2007] FMCA 690 distinguished M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 by applying the Full Federal Court in Uddin v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FCAFC 218 ; [2005] FCAFC 218 ; (2005) 149 FCR 1. The Tribunal observes that, in particular, Riley FM felt that the Tribunal retained discretion to invite an applicant to a hearing, notwithstanding the applicant's failure to respond to an invitation under section 359A of the Act.

The Tribunal has decided to proceed to a decision on the basis of the material before it.

Further, the Tribunal, pursuant to s.360 has made a decision on the review without inviting the applicant to appear before it. The Tribunal finds that s 359C(2) applies and therefore s.360(2)(c) is relevant. The Tribunal finds that it is unable to allow the applicant to appear before it ( MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 and M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247). Pursuant to ss. 360 and 363A of the Act, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision on the review without holding a hearing.

[49] I do not see how, having regard to the language of s 424B(2) or the scope of Div 4, a breach which consisted of giving an applicant more time than he or she was entitled to, could be thought to render invalid a decision given after the breach. The effect of s.363A appears to be to remove any discretion. The issue was considered by his Honour Tracey J in M v Minister for Immigration [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 91 ALD 629. At [39] - [46] his Honour said: Section 360 of the Act ensures that, subject to certain limited exceptions, all applicants are invited to appear before the Tribunal to give evidence and make submissions in support of their applications. One of the exceptions, provided for in s 360(2)(c) of the Act arises where s 359C(1) of the Act applies to an applicant. Section 359C(1) of the Act so applies where an invitation to provide additional information has been extended under s 359 and that information has not been provided within the time stipulated in the letter of invitation. That is of no consequence, however, if the Tribunal (contrary to its assumption) had no discretion. The effect of s.363A appears to be to remove any discretion. The issue was considered by his Honour Tracey J in M v Minister for Immigration [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 91 ALD 629. At [39] - [46] his Honour said: Section 360 of the Act ensures that, subject to certain limited exceptions, all applicants are invited to appear before the Tribunal to give evidence and make submissions in support of their applications. One of the exceptions, provided for in s 360(2)(c) of the Act arises where s 359C(1) of the Act applies to an applicant. Section 363A provides, in that situation, that the Tribunal 'does not have power to permit the person to do that thing'. There is a lack of unanimity in the authorities as to whether s 363A deprives the Tribunal of any discretion to invite the review applicant to attend a hearing, once s 360(2) and (3) come into operation. [26] If necessary the Minister would submit that s 363A does have that effect. However, the issue does not need to be resolved: the Tribunal proceeded on the basis that it did have a discretion but was not prepared to exercise it. [27] The issue that arises (and is pursued in the Applicant's written submissions) is whether the reasoning of the High Court in SZBEL somehow trumps the effect of ss 360(2) and (3). These proceedings began with a show cause application filed on 4 November 2008. The applicant later filed an amended application after having obtained legal representation. I conducted a show cause hearing on that amended application on 6 March 2009. At that hearing I ordered the Minister to show cause why relief should not be granted in relation to the issue of whether the applicant's failure to respond to a letter dated 4 August 2008 [22] deprived the applicant of a hearing pursuant to s.360 of the Migration Act , having regard to s.363A of the Migration and the decisions of Minister for Immigration & Citizenship v Sun [2008] FCAFC 201 and M v Minister for Immigration [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 91 ALD 629 and the decision of the High Court in SZBEL v Minister for Immigration [2006] HCA 63 ; (2006) 228 CLR 152.

On 24 March 2009, the Tribunal wrote to the applicant advising that as a result of her failure to respond to the Tribunal's s.359(2) letter of 18 February 2009 within the prescribed time period, she has lost her entitlement to be invited to a hearing pursuant to s.360(3) and the Tribunal is precluded from offering her a hearing in this circumstance: s.363A of the Act; MIMIA v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 ; Lee v MIAC [2007] FMCA 1802. Accordingly, she was informed that a hearing in relation to her case cannot be conducted and the Tribunal has decided to make a decision on the review on the basis of the evidence before it without taking any further action to obtain any additional information. The applicant, however, was advised that the Tribunal would not take any steps to finalise her case until 7 April 2009 and would consider any material which is submitted on or before that date.

Notwithstanding, the Tribunal also notes that Riley FM in Khergamwala v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2007] FMCA 690 distinguished M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 by applying the decision of the Full Federal Court in Uddin v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FCAFC 218 ; (2005) 149 FCR 1. The Tribunal observes that, in particular, Riley FM considered that the Tribunal retained discretion to invite an applicant to a hearing, notwithstanding the applicant's failure to respond to an invitation under section 359A of the Act. Under section 363A, the Tribunal does not have the power to permit a person to do something he or she is not entitled to do, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise. Section 360 does not provide otherwise. In M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 (29 September 2006), the Federal Court of Australia confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have had to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing, notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so. On this basis, as the applicant failed to give the comments and information within the prescribed statutory period, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the comments in accordance with section 359C of the Act.

Further, the Tribunal, pursuant to s. 360 has made a decision on the review without inviting the applicant to appear before it. The Tribunal finds that s 359C(2) applies and therefore s 360(2)(c) is relevant. The authorities such as MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 and M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247 suggest that the Tribunal is unable to allow the applicant to appear before it. In any event, the Tribunal considers that it would not exercise its discretion to allow the applicant to appear before it to give evidence and present arguments because the applicant had not provided any reasons for his failure to comment or respond to Tribunal's invitation and had not requested an opportunity to appear before the Tribunal and it is not apparent to the Tribunal that the applicant had been unable to provide his comments or response. Pursuant to ss. 360 and 363A of the Act, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision on the review without holding a hearing. The applicant wrote to the Tribunal after the prescribed period had passed, seeking an extension of time. The Tribunal is of the view that it is unable to grant an extension of time after the prescribed period has passed (see, for example, M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247 at [52] ). However, even if the Tribunal was able to grant an extension of time, the Tribunal would not have exercised its discretion to do so. This is because the applicant's letter, received on 22 January 2009, does not specify what documents the applicant needs delivered or why the delivery of documents has been delayed. While the applicant refers to public holidays, the Tribunal notes that the documents the applicant was requested to provide was a copy of his passport, evidence of his past and current study and evidence relating to his English ability. Most, if not all, of these documents could reasonably be expected to be in the applicant's possession. Thus, the Tribunal determines not to grant the applicant more time to provide the documents. The Tribunal determines, pursuant to s. 359C, to make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the additional information or the applicant's views on the information.

Notwithstanding, the Tribunal also notes that Riley FM in Khergamwala v Minister for Immigration & Anor [2007] FMCA 690 distinguished M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 by applying the Full Federal Court in Uddin v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FCAFC 218 ; (2005) 149 FCR 1. The Tribunal observes that, in particular, Riley FM felt that the Tribunal retained discretion to invite an applicant to a hearing, notwithstanding the applicant's failure to respond to an invitation under section 359A of the Act. As the review applicant has failed to give the additional information requested before the time for giving it has passed, subsection 359C(1) applies and the Tribunal may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the information. Further, as subsection 359C(1) applies to the review applicant, subsection 360(3) states that the review applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. Under section 363A the Tribunal does not have the power to permit a person to do something he or she is not entitled to do, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise. Section 360 does not provide otherwise and, as the review applicant has failed to give the additional information within the prescribed statutory period. In addition, the Tribunal notes that the decision in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so. On this basis, as the review applicant failed to give the information within the prescribed statutory period, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the information in accordance with section 359C of the Act.

Accordingly, a hearing in relation to her case could not be conducted and the Tribunal decided to make a decision on the review on the basis of the evidence before it without taking any further action to obtain any comments or additional information.

Notwithstanding, the Tribunal also notes that Riley FM in Khergamwala v. Minister for Immigration & Anor [2007] FMCA 690 distinguished M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 by applying the Full Federal Court in Uddin v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2005] FCAFC 218 ; (2005) 149 FCR 1. The Tribunal observes that, in particular, Riley FM felt that the Tribunal retained discretion to invite an applicant to a hearing, notwithstanding the applicant's failure to respond to an invitation under section 359A of the Act. In addition, the Tribunal notes that the decision in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so.

In Kergamwala v MIAC & Anor [2007] FMCA 690 , Riley FM discussed the conflicting positions as articulated in Uddin v MIMIA [2005] FCAFC 218 , MIMIA v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 and M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247.

23. The Tribunal exceeded its jurisdiction by holding that hearing, but, in doing so, it did not deny the applicant procedural fairness. Indeed, this is a case where, irrespective of any question of procedural fairness or individual merits, the decision-maker was bound to affirm the delegate's decision. As a consequence, the applicant suffered no injustice by reason of the Tribunal's action in excess of jurisdiction when it gave him an opportunity to give evidence and put arguments as to why the decision of the delegate should not be affirmed. Consequently, notwithstanding that jurisdictional error has been demonstrated by reason that the Tribunal held a hearing when it had no power to do so, relief will nevertheless be refused in the exercise of the Court's discretion: Re Refugee Review Tribunal; ex parte Aala [2000] HCA 57 ; (2000) 204 CLR 82 ; SAAP v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs (2005) 215 ALR 162 ; M v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333.
22. The Minister's submissions raised the issue of whether a jurisdictional error might be identified in the fact that the Tribunal had held a hearing at all. This arose in circumstances where the Tribunal was not obliged under s.360 to invite the applicant to a hearing because he had failed to respond to the s.359A notice. The interaction of ss.362 and 363 and 359C (2) have this effect. Significantly, s.363A provides:
If a provision of this Part states that a person is not entitled to do something, or to be assisted or represented by another person, then, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise, the Tribunal does not have power to permit the person to do that thing, or to be assisted or represented by another person.
Consequently, the Tribunal had no power to hold the hearing to which it invited the applicant: M v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at 345-346 [46] .

In M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 , Tracey J held that s.363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal might have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so.

Alternatively, if the Tribunal follows the authority in MIMIA v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 or M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 then where s.359C applies as a result of the operation of sections 360(3) and 363A the Tribunal would not invite the applicant to a hearing because it considers that it is precluded from doing so. On 24 November 2006 the Tribunal wrote to the agent and advised the request for an extension of time in which to respond had been refused as the request was made after the due date (see: M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247). Riley FM considered she was bound to follow Uddin , in preference to MIMIA v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 or M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 irrespective of whether it was wrongly decided (per incuriam).

As a result of the operation of sections 360(3) and 363A of the Migration Act 1958 and in accordance with M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247 the applicant no longer has an entitlement to appear before the Tribunal.

16. The Tribunal stated as well in its letter dated 13 October 2006 (CB 132):
If the Tribunal does not receive any comments within the period allowed or as extended, it may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain your comments or to invite you to appear before the Tribunal.
The Tribunal therefore complied with s.359C(1) of the Act , which provides that if a person does not give the information before the time for giving it has passed the Tribunal may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the additional information. The Tribunal did however consider information received on 5 December 2006 (CB 144-145). The Tribunal complied with the Act and was entitled to make a decision on the review without conducting a hearing. As s.359C(1) and (2) apply to the applicant, the applicant was not entitled to appear before the Tribunal: s.360(2)(c) and s. 360 (3). The Court refers to the decision of Tracey J in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 91 ALD 629 at [46] as follows:
Section 363A operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have had to permit an applicant to appear notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so.
Ground three is rejected.

Section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have had to permit an applicant to appear notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so ( M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 , (2006) 91 ALD 629 and Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 , (2005) 146 FCR 498 ). At the oral hearing the applicant argued that the cases of M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 91 ALD 629 and Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; (2005) 146 FCR 498 concerned a situation in which only one set of circumstances had given rise to the obligation to invite the applicant to a hearing but in the present case, there was the initial set of circumstances and then a second set of circumstances consisting of the information provided in the submission dated 20 September 2006 that gave rise to new issues before the Tribunal and a fresh obligation to provide a hearing.

The Tribunal notes that the invitation to comment and to give additional information was sent by registered post to the last address for service provided by the visa applicant in connection with the application for review. The Tribunal has evidence indicating the date of dispatch in accordance with section 379A of the Act (T1, f.134), and the visa applicant's authorised recipient has acknowledged receipt of the letter. As the visa applicant has failed within the prescribed period to provide comments as requested under section 359A and to give the additional information requested under section 359(2), subsections 359C(1) and 359C(2) apply and the Tribunal may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the visa applicant's comments or the additional information. Further, as subsections 359C(1) and 359C(2) apply to the visa applicant, subsection 360(3) states that the visa applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal: see M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247. Under section 363A, the Tribunal does not have the power to permit a person to do something he or she is not entitled to do, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise. Section 360 does not provide otherwise and as the visa applicant has failed to give the comments and additional information before the end of the prescribed period, the Tribunal will proceed to make a decision on the review in accordance with section 359C of the Act without taking any further action to obtain the visa applicant's comments or the additional information.

As the visa applicant has failed to give the information requested before the time for giving it has passed, subsections 359C(1) and (2) apply and the Tribunal may make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the information. Further, as subsections 359C(1) and (2) apply to the visa applicant, subsection 360(3) states that the visa applicant is not entitled to appear before the Tribunal. Under section 363A the Tribunal does not have the power to permit a person to do something he or she is not entitled to do, unless a provision expressly provides otherwise. Section 360 does not provide otherwise and as the visa applicant has failed to give the information within the prescribed statutory period, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision on the review without taking any further action to obtain the information in accordance with section 359C of the Act. In addition, the Tribunal notes that the decision in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 confirmed that section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so.

M v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 155 FCR 333 at [35] - [38], and SZEXZ v Minister for Immigration, Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs [2006] FCA 449 at [30] - [49]).

363A and 360 (2)(c) and (3); MIMIA v Jing Shan Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 ; M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 FINDINGS AND REASONS
For the reasons that follow, the Tribunal is not satisfied on the basis of the material before it that the visa applicant is the spouse of the review applicant within the meaning of r.1.15A of the Regulations.
[22] Therefore, no jurisdictional error can be disclosed by its refusal to extend time. This is similar reasoning to that expressed by Tracey J in M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 at [36] --- [37].

27. In the Federal Court judgment, M v MIMA [2006] FCA 1247 , delivered on 29 September 2006, the applicant sought judicial review of a Tribunal decision affirming a decision of the Minister's delegate to cancel his Global Special Humanitarian (Class BA) subclass 202 visa. The applicant's visa was cancelled on the basis that he had made false claims in relation to his citizenship as well as in relation to other matters in support of his original visa application. The application was dismissed and among other matters Tracey J held as follows: Section 363A of the Act operates to remove any residual discretion the Tribunal may have to permit an applicant to appear at a hearing notwithstanding his or her loss of an entitlement to do so. The language of the section is clear. No legislative intention can be discerned that a misstatement of the prescribed period in a s.359(2) letter should lead to the invalidity of the Tribunal's ultimate decision in circumstances where the time stated was more generous than that prescribed, the applicant did not respond within the time stated, the applicant subsequently provided the information sought and that information was taken into account by the Tribunal.

As in Uddin v MIMA [2005] FCAFC 218 ; (2005) 149 FCR 1 at [61] there is nothing to suggest that the Tribunal proceeded on an assumption that it was not entitled to grant the applicant a hearing (cf the statutory provisions considered in M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247 ; (2006) 91 ALD 629 at [39] --- [55]).

The Tribunal notes that the Full Federal Court recently held in M v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 that the obligation to stipulate correctly the prescribed period does not extend in mandatory terms to circumstances where the time stipulated is more generous than that prescribed.
The Tribunal finds that it is unable to allow the applicant to appear before it ( MIMIA v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201 and M v MIMIA [2006] FCA 1247).

I was referred to the decisions of the Federal Court in M v Minister for Immigration & Multicultural Affairs [2006] FCA 1247 ; Minister for Immigration & Multicultural & Indigenous Affairs v Sun [2005] FCAFC 201.
